>
>  The latter, as I described in either my original or second post on
>  this thread.  The point of having separate networks is to be able to
>  have a fixed number of inputs, which wouldn't be possible otherwise
>  due to variations in the betting rounds and the number of cards on the
>  board.
>

I'm not sure I completely agree with the assumption that we should be
representing the table "literally".  I feel like there's simply too
much information there.  Again, if we can come up with a way to
"decompose" the table into meaningful vectors, I think we gain a lot
of ground.  In short, I think the set of all data available may be
overkill.  Has anyone really solved any problems of this magnitude?
Not to be completely skeptical but I feel like people are
underestimating the amount of data available at any given moment in a
poker game.

>
>  I am really excited about the idea of parallelizing NEAT as a first
>  step, actually.  The downside here might be that we would be cutting
>  it close for the competition deadline.  However, I think we can work
>  on the two at the same time by using a serial implementation and then
>  later converting it over (which should be seamless).
>

I should be very happy if we had something for the 2010 competition.

>  The first step for the poker code would probably be to get a
>  simulation engine that we can all agree is sufficient.  Most of my
>  code is psuedo-windows proprietary.  It was written with the idea of
>  scraping a poker table's screen and composing a game state from that,
>  and I didn't lay out the headers very well, so there's a couple of

come again?

>  things that won't compile on linux.  However, I used only STL
>  containers, so the logic should compile fine.  If you guys wanted to
>  use mine (at least as a quick and dirty implementation), I'll see if I
>  can refactor the code this weekend and upload it somewhere.  I'd
>  certainly be open to a different (likely better) engine if there's one
>  freely available in C++.  Either way, please let me know.
>

As far as pure simulation of the game, it sounds fine.  Again, I don't
think running the game itself is the problem.  It's everything else
that needs to be fast (although, obviously it wouldn't hurt).

regards,

jeff



-- 
...imagine a puddle waking up one morning and thinking, 'This is an
interesting world I find myself in, an interesting hole I find myself
in, fits me rather neatly, doesn't it? In fact it fits me staggeringly
well, must have been made to have me in it!' This is such a powerful
idea that as the sun rises in the sky and the air heats up and as,
gradually, the puddle gets smaller and smaller, it's still frantically
hanging on to the notion that everything's going to be alright,
because this world was meant to have him in it, was built to have him
in it; so the moment he disappears catches him rather by surprise. I
think this may be something we need to be on the watch out for.

-- Douglas Adams
